title: SB 1325
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to require the department to review and approve plans submitted under Section 25246 if they comply with regulations and state/federal laws. Approval may be delayed until certain conditions are met, including approval under the Water Code or if immediate approval is necessary for public health or safety. The director may approve a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan if it is necessary for public health, safety, or the environment. The plan must comply with the California Environmental Quality Act. The hazardous waste facility postclosure plan must be approved in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act. The department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying the plan. A "significant modification" for hazardous waste facilities is determined based on similarity to class 3 modifications in regulations. Public concern and complexity also influence the classification of a modification. The department has the authority to order necessary actions at a facility to protect public health and safety, regardless of any limitations or delays imposed by this subdivision. If the department requires a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan through an enforcement order or agreement, the owner must pay a specified fee or enter a cost reimbursement agreement. The fee is due at the start of the postclosure period, defined as the effective date of the permit, order, or agreement. The department may enforce a postclosure plan through various actions, including filing an injunction, requiring corrective actions, and assessing civil penalties for violations. This does not apply to plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. On or before January 1, 2018, the department will adopt regulations for postclosure plan requirements. If deemed necessary, the department can replace an enforcement order with a postclosure permit for a hazardous waste facility. Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code is amended to ensure that plans submitted comply with regulations and state/federal laws. The department has the authority to order actions to protect public health, safety, and the environment without delay. The plan for an interim status facility must be approved within 60 days of submission to the department, with a provision for resubmission if denied. Immediate approval may be granted to protect public health, safety, or the environment. Department actions are subject to Section 25204.5, and hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements can be imposed through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits. The department can impose hazardous waste facility postclosure requirements on owners or operators through enforcement orders, agreements, or permits, in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act. The California Environmental Quality Act requires approval of hazardous waste facility postclosure plans imposed or modified by enforcement orders, permits, or agreements. The Department must allow public involvement before approving or modifying these plans. The Department determines if a modification is significant based on class 3 permit criteria. Public concern and complexity are also considered for class 3 modifications. The Department has the authority to order actions at a facility to protect public health or safety. If a hazardous waste facility postclosure plan is imposed by the department, the owner or operator must enter into a cost reimbursement agreement and pay the required fee at the commencement of the postclosure period. The Department can enforce postclosure plans through various actions, including seeking injunctions, requiring corrective actions, and imposing civil penalties for violations. This does not apply to plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. The Department may enforce postclosure plans through actions like injunctions, corrective measures, and penalties. Plans with permits issued before December 31, 2003, are exempt unless mutually replaced with an enforcement order or agreement. Regulations for postclosure plan requirements must be adopted by January 1, 2018. The Department can replace an enforcement order or agreement with a postclosure permit if necessary. The department has the authority to order actions to protect public health, safety, or the environment at a facility. Section 1.5 of the bill includes amendments to Section 25247 of the Health and Safety Code, contingent on the enactment of Assembly Bill 1611 or Senate Bill 839 by January 1, 2017. If this bill is enacted last, the amended Section 25247 will only be operative until the effective date of this bill.
